story: UK negotiators say continued full participation in&nbspGalieo is a 'test case' for close cooperation on securityThe British government has threatened weaker security cooperation and intelligence sharing with the EU after Brexit if the UK is excluded from the Galileo satellite navigation system once it leaves the bloc.¬†A presentation drawn up by the British negotiating team and shown to EU officials warns that continued access to the system is a ‚Äútest case‚Äù in the eyes of the UK for how closely Britain and the EU cooperate on security matters after they leave.The move is likely to enrage Brussels, where senior figures have previously accused the UK of trying to blackmail the EU by using its strengths in intelligence and security as a bargaining chip in talks.The Galileo system is an EU-developed and built¬†equivalent¬†to¬†GPS, which is operated by the US military. The European system has a number of technical advantages over the existing generation of GPS¬†and would be operated independently by Europe without reliance on the US.The presentation drawn up by British negotiators¬†outlines how the UK and EU could build a¬†strong security partnership after Brexit, but adds:¬†‚ÄúThe arrangements for any UK cooperation on Galileo are an important test case of the depth of operational cooperation and information sharing envisaged under the security partnership.‚ÄùBritish officials said it would be harder for the UK to work closely with the EU on security without full participation in the scheme.The UK negotiators said they want ‚Äúcontinued UK participation in the development and operation of the open signal‚Äù of the system despite the UK leaving the bloc, as well as¬†access to the private regulated signal for British armed forces.One year to Brexit: What is still needed to complete a deal with the EU?They have also demanded that British defence firms must be allowed to bid for contracts on the EU‚Äôs secure network on the same ‚Äúfair‚Äù basis as EU firms despite Britain‚Äôs departure.The European Commission has already moved to relocate a backup control centre for Galileo from Britain because of Brexit, with operations underway to relocate it to Spain.Brussels has also moved to lock Britain‚Äôs defence industry out of bidding for contracts related to the ‚Ç¨10bn¬†(¬£8.8bn)¬†programme ‚Äì which prompted the defence secretary, Gavin Williamson, to warn that the move would be ‚Äúdetrimental to European security‚Äù.The UK presentation said Britain will move to develop its own satellite system to compete with Galileo if it doesn‚Äôt get full continued participation in the project.David Davis, the Brexit secretary, last year denied the UK was threatening the EU over defence and security to get a better deal, after Theresa May said no deal would be bad for security. ‚ÄúThis is not a threat. This is a statement of the fact that this will be harmful for both of us if we don‚Äôt get a deal,‚Äù he said at the time.The first Galileo satellite was launched in 2005 and the system is expected to be completed by 2020, with early operational capability planned for later this year and full capability by 2019. Its public system will be accurate to one¬†metre and its encrypted version will be accurate to one centimetre.Brexit so far: in picturesBrexit so far: in picturesBoris Johnson MP, Labour MP Gisela Stuart and UKIP MP Douglas Carswell address the people of Stafford in Market Square during the Vote Leave Brexit Battle Bus tour on 17 May 2016. Their lead line on the tour was: ‚ÄúWe send the EU ¬£350 million a week, let's fund our NHS instead.‚ÄùA man shelters from the rain as he arrives at a polling station in London on 23 June 2016. Millions of Britons voted in the referendum on whether to stay in or leave the European Union.Leader of Ukip, Nigel Farage, reacts at the Leave EU referendum party at Millbank Tower in central London as results indicated that it looked likely the UK would leave the European Union.A young couple painted as EU flags and a man with a sign reading ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not leaving‚Äù protest outside Downing Street against the voters decision to leave the EU on 24 June 2016.British Prime Minister David Cameron resigns on the steps of 10 Downing Street on 24 June 2016 after the results of the EU referendum were declared and the United Kingdom voted to leave the European UnionTheresa May receives a kiss from her husband Philip, after becoming the new Conservative Party leader on 11 July 2016. Where she spoke about her offer to introduce a transition period after the UK formally leaves the European Union in March 2019.&#13British Prime Minister Theresa May in the cabinet, sitting below a painting of Britain's first Prime Minister Robert Walpole, signs the official letter to European Council President Donald Tusk invoking Article 50 and the United Kingdom's intention to leave the EU on 29 March 2017.Soon after triggering Article 50, Theresa May called on 18 April for a snap general election. title: pro wrestling eve wrestle queendom women safe space rights feminism wwe
story: A revolution is not a one-time event.That quote from American author, activist and feminist Audre Lorde hung proudly from a banner at the historic York Hall in Bethnal Green on 5 May, 2018. This short quote from Lorde's 1982 essay Learning from the 60s&nbspmight not have much to do with professional wrestling but, in many ways, it encapsulated everything that happened in the building - and indeed the ring - that evening.&nbspPro-Wrestling: EVE's Wrestle Queendom, the largest all-female wrestling show in Europe ever, was a prime example of what a revolution looks like. This wasn't just a huge step for wrestling, but for women, feminism and equality as a whole. As indy100 detailed last week, EVE's progressive liberal politics and ethos supporting women's rights, LGBT+ equality, body positivity and mental health discussions have helped create a wrestling promotion unlike any other.&nbspAs a wrestling fan from the age of six, I've seen a lot of events and many at York Hall but, in all honesty, I've never experienced anything like what happened at Wrestle Queendom. The energy in the building and the collective sense of being part of something historic resonated with everyone inside. Not only was this a fantastic wrestling show but it was an all-encompassing example of how society can learn to treat everyone better.&nbspWe did it üíöüí™üçè #wrestlequeendom #girlgang #womensrevolution #womenswrestling #womenswrestlingrevolution #feministlondonA post shared by  EVE Wrestling (@prowrestlingeve) on May 7, 2018 at 1:20am PDTThe show started out with EVE co-owner Emily Read addressing the crowd from the stage. Although the show started later than planned, the emphasis on creating a safe space for everyone in attendance was clear from the start. When taking a not-so-subtle dig at WWE's recent controversial show in Saudi Arabia, Emily demanded that no racism, homophobia, hate speech, body shaming, sexism or harassment would be tolerated.&nbspIt seems bizarre but oddly encouraging that a wrestling company - where staged violence is the main port of call - should be promoting these values. Seriously, other sporting events and music festivals could learn so much from the way EVE value their fans and their safety. It creates an environment where everyone feels comfortable, no matter who they are, and are allowed to enjoy themselves without feeling threatened. Cheer and boo who you want, by all means, but be respectful.As for the actual show, it has potential to be one of the best wrestling shows to take place anywhere on the planet this year. It featured a brutal 'War Games' cage match (the first time a women's match of this kind has ever happened), a hilarious contest featuring the incredibly charismatic Kris Wolf and Jetta, a breathtaking ladder match, a show-stealing bout between Meiko Satomura and Kay Lee Ray, an international dream battle pitting Viper against Japanese legend Aja Kong and the main-event, which featured possibly the biggest reaction and outpouring of emotion ever heard in York Hall as the inspirational Charlie Morgan defeated Sammi Jayne to win the EVE championship.&nbspThe quality of this show cannot be underestimated and the wrestling community, fans and performers alike, came out to praise the event and what EVE stands for.Besides the wrestling, one of the biggest announcements of the evening was the introducing of the EVE Hall of Fame, which will be housed at the Bishopsgate Institute in London and will champion the shining lights in female wrestling from all over the world.&nbspThe library has one the largest archives of feminist and women's history, and LGBT+ history and activism, in the UK - and EVE will now have their own place in their hallowed walls. This prestigious moment was confirmed by Emily at Wrestle Queendom, with the first official inductee being British wrestling icon Klondyke Kate.&nbspIf you have any negative preconceptions about what women's wrestling is or can be I would implore you to go and see an EVE show or check out their online streaming service. This is a genuine grassroots movement&nbspwith a sense of family and with an attitude that should be applied to all walks of life. EVE is uplifting, empowering and promotes positivity for women and any minority through the vehicle of professional wrestling. They will change your opinion on what wrestling can and should be and, judging by Wrestle Queendom, they're only just getting started.&nbspMore:&nbspA feminist group are trying to ban a game about picking up women for next articleWe use cookies to enhance your visit to our site and to bring you advertisements that might interest you. Dog owners warned they face CRACKDOWN for having dogs in cars                Driving with a dog - Precautions you need to take to avoid up to &pound2...Inside a locked vehicle, the air can quickly reach killer temperatures as the design of most automobile glass creates a greenhouse effect trapping heat inside &ndash meaning dogs can succumb to heatstroke and die within a mere six minutes.Animal welfare campaigners had warned&nbspmotorists to ensure&nbsptheir pets were not left unattended in parked cars when&nbspforecasters predicted the&nbsprecord-breaking hot spell, but the&nbspmessage continues to be ignored.Last year the number of cases hit a worrying spike, with&nbspthe charity receiving 7,876&nbspcalls to its cruelty line,&nbsp90 per&nbspcent&nbsprelating to dogs. The RSPCA&nbspmay not be able to&nbspattend quickly enough&nbspand, with no powers of entry, we&rsquod need police&nbspassistance&nbspat such an incident.&middot If the animal is displaying any&nbspsign of heatstroke, such as panting heavily, drooling&nbspexcessively, is lethargic&nbspor uncoordinated, or&nbspcollapsed and vomiting, call 999&nbspimmediately.&middot If the situation becomes critical&nbspand police can&rsquot attend, many people&rsquos instinct is to break&nbspinto the car to&nbspfree the dog. Be aware that,&nbspwithout proper justification, this&nbspcould be classed as criminal damage. Make sure you tell the police of your&nbspintentions&nbspand take photos or footage&nbspof the dog as well as names and numbers&nbspof witnesses. The&nbsplaw states that you have a lawful excuse to commit damage if&nbspyou believe that the&nbspowner&nbspof the property that you damage would consent to the&nbspdamage if they knew the&nbspcircumstances.&middot Once&nbspremoved from the car, move the dog to a shadedcool area and pour small amounts&nbspof cool water over their body. Don&rsquot use cold&nbspwater as this could put your pet&nbspinto shock.&nbspAllow the dog to drink small amounts of cool water. Once the dog is&nbspcool take him the to&nbspnearest vet as&nbspa matter of urgency.* If&nbspthe dog isn&rsquot displaying signs of heatstroke, establish how long the dog has&nbspbeen in the&nbspcar and make a note of the registration. Ask a&nbspmember of staff to&nbspmake an&nbspannouncement of the situation over the tannoy, if possible, and get&nbspsomeone to stay with&nbspthe dog to monitor its&nbspcondition.&nbsp* You can call the&nbspRSPCA&rsquos 24-hour emergency cruelty line on 0300 1234 999 for advice but, if a&nbspdog is in danger, dialling 999 should&nbspalways be the first step.&nbsp

story: Angy Ellis  North NewsAround 20 to 30 dolphins were spotted swimming in HartlepoolAngy Ellis, a photographer, was riding her jet ski in the North Sea with three friends when she spotted fins in the distance.The group, who planned a trip to the landmark Steetley Pier, noticed splashes in the sea and after initially mistaking the sea creatures for porpoises realised they had found a pod of around 25 dolphins.Ms Ellis, of Hartlepool, said: &ldquoThe dolphins swam past us and we had to speed a little bit to keep up with them, it was quite difficult.&ldquoAll of a sudden we thought, we&rsquoll slow down and watch them from a far.                Virgin Holidays: Sustainable pledge gives &pound200K for dolphin sanctuary                WATCH: Harrowing moment ARMY of sea creatures finds unlucky surfer&ldquoIt was magical, they swam over to us, they followed us.&ldquoWe couldn&rsquot even count how many there were, around 20 to 30, and they were all swimming with us.&ldquoThey were right beside us.Ms Ellis, who has been jet skiing for eight years, added: &ldquoThe dolphins were having fun with the skis.&ldquoI decided to jump in, only one dolphin swam close to me but I could tell they were around by my feet.&ldquoI was crying it was so beautiful, it was amazing, it was breathtaking.&ldquoWe could have been anywhere in the world.&ldquoPeople travel thousands of miles to swim with dolphins or even just to see them and don&rsquot get that lucky, and they are on our doorstep.Angy Ellis  North NewsAngy Ellis jumped into the water with the dolphins, one swam close byMs Ellis was with three other members of a Jetski group based at the Tees &amp Hartlepool Yacht Club, when she encountered the dolphins over the Bank Holiday weekend.She added: &ldquoThe pod followed us all the way to the headland.&ldquoWe were with them for about 15 to 20 minutes.&ldquoIt&rsquos important to say that we respect marine animals so we weren&rsquot trying to bother them or touch them, we just followed them gently and let them swim by us.&ldquoIt was amazing and I hope it happens again.

title: Brexit news House Lords peers abolish scrap petition politics Jacob Rees Mogg referendum
story: The backlash against the upper chamber comes amid growing anger at Remainer peers' attempts to frustrate the Brexit process.The petition &ndash which was created on February 17 &ndash has garnered 153,602 signatures from angry Britons, and is continuing to pick up mass support.The huge support for the petition means the issue will be debated in the House of Parliament on June 18.It could spell the end of almost 700 years of unelected peers wielding power in Britain.                Brexit shock as peers vote to keep Britain shackled to EU agencies                Lord Lawson makes BRILLIANT point about why EU wants a BAD Brexit dealAnd according to an online poll of 6,700 Express readers, 94 percent of respondents believe the House of Lords should be abolished.Peers have come under intense criticism from Eurosceptics in recent weeks for what they view as attempting to water down Theresa May's Brexit plans.The Lords has already dealt 13 defeats to the Government on its EU Withdrawal Bill.Peers voted for a series of amendments to the landmark legislation which include changes which stop Britain achieving a clean Brexit.The amendments need to be agreed by MPs before they become binding.However, Mrs May has a working majority of just 13 seats in the House of Commons, meaning she is left vulnerable by every vote on Brexit.&bullPARLIAMENT153,000 people backed a petition calling for a referendum on axing the House of LordsWhat's the purpose of the House of Lords? How do you become a Lord? What are the House of Lords traditions? All these answers explained.1 of 25The petition, set up by Robert McBride, calls on Parliament to give the electorate a referendum on the abolition of the House of Lords.It reads: The House of Lords is a place of patronage where unelected and unaccountable iniduals hold a disproportionate amount of influence and power which can be used to frustrate the elected representatives of the people.Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg has accused peers of attempting to frustrate the Government's Brexit process after their latest intervention in the House of Lords.He said: The peers set themselves against the people, using an ermine-covered wrecking ball in their efforts to stop Brexit. But ultimately, democracy will triumph.Jacob Rees-Mogg accused peers of attempting to frustrate the Brexit processFellow Conservative MP Peter Bone, who played a leading role in the Leave campaign, said peers threatening to block Brexit were doing a great disservice to the country.He added: When it's an unelected House that's deliberately trying to thwart the will of the people, then something seriously has gone wrong.And earlier today, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson urged the upper house to respect the clearly mandated will of the British people.He said: There is a longstanding tradition in the UK that the House of Lords can under no circumstances frustrate what has been clearly mandated not just by a referendum but by the election as well.'Indeed, they shouldn't frustrate it under any circumstances because they do not represent they sovereign will of the British people.'Boris Johnson urged the upper house to respect the will of the British peopleUkip's deputy leader Mike Hookem backed the petition, saying it was time to replace the archaic and anti-democratic House of Lords with an elected upper chamber.He told Express: The House of Lords is becoming its own worst enemy in trying to reverse the will of the electorate and keep the UK in the EU by any means possible.Peers have no faith in the British people to govern ourselves and prosper without the interference of the EU in every aspect of our daily lives.Not one of these people, who sit in sneering judgment of the 17.4 million people who voted for Brexit, has been elected to hold such power over our democratic process.It is time to make Britain truly democratic and replace the House of Lords with an elected upper chamber with fixed terms of office.

story: The 92-year-old enjoyed the warmer weather in a white linen shirt, tweed skirt and a light blue cardigan as she enjoyed the first day of equestrian action in Berkshire.The monarch has attended the prestigious event, held in Windsor Castle's private grounds, every year since it was first held in 1943 to help raise funds for the war effort.The Queen and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, have competed in it for more than 30 years - with Prince Philip participating in the Carriage Driving event, which he won once in 1982.&nbspBut on Wednesday, there was no sign of Prince Philip, who is recovering from a hip operation that he underwent earlier this year.&nbsp                IRAN ISOLATED: Tehran blasts Europe will NOT be independent and is ... title: bayeux tapestry nasa planet nine queens university belfast
story: NASA and other space agencies have debated the idea that there could be an extra planet within our solar system which has so far gone undetected.The hypothetical Planet Nine is believed to be 10 times bigger than Earth and 20 times farther out from the sun than Neptune.While Planet Nine&rsquos existence has yet to be officially proven, esteemed researchers strongly suspect that there is a large planet lurking in the far edge of our solar system.If the planet is there, then it could explain why the solar system is slightly off balance.Bayeux Tapestry could help NASA unravel mystery of Planet Nine                Astronomers close to finding massive NINTH planet in the Solar System                Planet Nine: Could there be an EXTRA planet in our solar system? Halley's Comet can be seen on the Bayeux TapestryIn most star systems, the surrounding planets tend to rotate in line with their host.However, in ours, the planets are at an angle of six degrees off its axis.NASA believes that this is due to a huge planet and its gravitational pull tugging at our solar system.With experts unable to confirm its existence by analysing the skies, a duo from Queen&rsquos University Belfast are hoping the Anglo-Saxons can answer the question with clues potentially left in the 950-year old Bayeux Tapestry.Planet 9 is theorised to exist on the edge of the solar systemIncluded in the Bayeux Tapestry is a picture of a comet, and in 1066, when the tapestry was created, there are documents which detail the passing of Halley&rsquos Comet.By creating simulations of the orbital path of Halley&rsquos comet, experts may be able to decipher whether Planet Nine has had an effect on it.Pedro Lacerda, an astronomer at Queen&rsquos University Belfast, told Live Science: We can take the orbits of comets currently known and use a computer to calculate the times when those comets would be visible in the skies during the Middle Ages.The precise times depend on whether our computer simulations include Planet Nine.&ldquoSo, in simple terms, we can use the medieval comet sightings to check which computer simulations work best: the ones that include Planet Nine or the ones that do not.

story: North News &amp PicturesArtist thought his former teacher would have been 'proud that I had got this far'Ted Parker, 68, had been completing paintings and photographs for his latest exhibition when he suddenly thought how his art teacher &ldquowould have been proud that I had got this far.So he decided to see if he could track his former art master Douglas Higgins to thank him for his early encouragement.&nbspMr Parker, from Yarm, was brought up in Sheffield, where he attended Birley Secondary School, but had not seen Mr Higgins since he leaving in the early 1960s.He went on to work as an industrial scientific photographer for British Steel in Teesside and then ran his own a video production company in Yarm, Action TV, before retiring to take up his earlier hobby of painting.                Parents must buy books at cash-strapped schools, claims survey                Meet the crime-busting super teacher who won $1million Anticipating tracking down his teacher would be like finding a daughter, Andrew and Dorothy, who then very kindly arranged for me to visit Douglas, who is now 103-years-old and as alert and sharp as ever he was.Mr Parker arrived at the care home with some of his forthcoming exhibition at Richmond Station in North Yorkshire this month is entitled Boats and Planes&hellip.But Mainly Trains.&nbspMr Parker said: &ldquoA lot of the paintings on show in the exhibition are of railway scenes, so Douglas and I talked about the steam train era.&ldquoWhen I presented Douglas with a copy of one of my books he said excitedly, 'This is marvellous that one of my boys has made such a success of his life'.&ldquoYou have made my day.&rsquoIn turn, Mr Parker's mentor gave him an autobiography he has written about himself.Mr Parker said: &ldquoIt was a fantastic pupil&rsquos future life.

title: cambridge university class lists results tradition
story: Punters on the Cam near St John's College, CambridgeResults have been published for all to see since 1748 in a custom known at the university as &ldquoclass lists.But students can now opt out from having their exam marks revealed publicly to protect them from &ldquodistress and harm.The decision comes after nearly three years of campaigning which began in June 2015 when the &ldquoOur Grade, Our Choice protest, led by Nadine Batchelor-Hunt and Freya Sorrell, was launched.Cambridge was the only university in Britain to still publicly display class lists after Oxford abolished the practice in 2009.                Snowflake Britain: Railway plaque with knight not &lsquoappropriate'                Millennial 'snowflakes' blame baby boomers for 'RUINING their lives'Cambridge&rsquos Student Union president Daisy Eyre described the ruling as &ldquofantastic.She said: &ldquoIt is clear that this is what students want and what makes sense for the future of the university.&ldquoIt's been a long time coming, but maybe we can turn the page on class lists for now.Class lists are usually posted on notice boards outside Senate House, published in the Cambridge University Reporter, and are available online.But the fellows of Regent House, which includes academics and other key figures, voted by 412 to 391 to bring an end to the tradition.Cambridge students will no longer have their results made publicGraham Virgo, pro-vice-chancellor for education, said: &ldquoI welcome the result of the ballot which means that all students are now able to choose to opt out from having their names published outside the Senate House or in the Reporter.&ldquoThis opt out will be implemented immediately. Faculties, departments and colleges will still have access to the full class list for their own internal purposes.Previously, students could only opt out in exceptional circumstances, after a lengthy, bureaucratic process, and only 86 names were omitted last year.Campaigners at the university, which has about 21,000 students from all round the world, claimed having their result made public for all to see could affect the mental health of some people.They said the lists are &ldquodamaging to welfare, can trigger depression and promote a culture of naming and shaming.Stunning students at Cambridge University got naked in the name of charity for a posh but raunchy calendar.1 of 10Martha Krish, students' union education officer, complained last year that the lists had caused distress and harm to countless students and the new system was &ldquoa massive improvement.Oxford has kept exam results private since October 2009 after 40 per cent of students opted out, citing the Data Protection Act.Supporters of the class lists said they were saddened to see a tradition dating back nearly 300 years being abolished.

title: UK hot weather forecast weekend heatwave long range summer 2018 forecast June Met Office
story: The next hot spell, due next week, could stretch into June&nbspwith golden&nbsprays&nbspand&nbspboiling&nbspthermometers kicking off&nbspsummer,&nbspaccording to&nbsplong-range forecasters.Parts of the country are continuing to bake in some of the highest temperatures ever seen at this time of year after a record-smashing bank holiday.The mercury rocketed to 28.7C (83.66F) in Northolt, London, on Monday making it the hottest May Day weekend in history.The southeast will hold onto the fine weather until mid-week while wind and rain from the Atlantic turn the heat down elsewhere.Temperatures will widely plunge around 10C through towards the weekend with highs of around 17C (62.6F) forecast by Saturday.Low-pressure systems sweeping in from the west will bring bouts of rain and cloudy skies mainly to western and northern regions, experts say.Violent thunderstorms triggered by extreme heat across the south will put the region on alert for torrential downpours and lightning from Tuesday night.However high pressure similar to that responsible for the weekend heatwave is expected to re-build across the nation next week.WX ChartsUK weather forecast: Heatwave to current models show another region of high pressure building.&ldquoWe think it might turn gradually warmer again through next week and while there is still a lot to play for, all the computer models temperatures will dwindle a little after Tuesday, however, despite this fall meaning it might not be as warm as the weekend, there will be ample sunny periods for many.&ldquoThe back end of the month and the start of June is likely to bring another heat surge to kick off the meteorological summer of 2018.&ldquoHowever, some of these warm to hot periods could become hampered by cloud cover at times giving a muggy feel to affairs.&ldquoThere could be some thunderstorm activity bringing hefty rain or hail showers but as a whole we expect temperatures to be at more near to above-average for the month.Extreme heat across the southeast has sparked warnings to be at the ready for&nbsp explosive thunderstorms through Tuesday night.Wet weather will set in across Scotland and the north on Wednesday morning before sweeping into England and Wales through the day.It is the warmest May bank holiday since records began.                    EPA1 of 18Eveyln, 4, runs down the beach with a bucket and spade as she enjoys the hot Bank Holiday weather in MargateThe mercury will hover around the 22C (71.6F) mark in the south before dropping to around 16C (60.8F) or 17C (62.6F) by Thursday, the Met Office said.Further showery outbreaks are forecast ahead of the weekend with southeastern England again expected to hold on to the best of the sunshine and dry weather.Miss Yeomans said: &ldquoIt is looking slightly unsettled for the weekend and it will feel cooler with temperatures in the mid to high teens.&ldquoThere is a chance of thunderstorms on Tuesday night in the southeast triggered by the warm weather and a plume of air pushing up from the south.&ldquoWednesday is looking like a similar day with a front coming in from the west bringing rain to Scotland and northern Ireland, by the afternoon this will have pushed into northwestern England, Wales and the southwest.&ldquoWe expect temperatures of around 22C (71.6F) in the southeast on Wednesday before a mixed bag of weather on Thursday sees these values drop to around 16C (60.8F) or 17C (62.6F) widely. BBC Weather forecast: UK to bask in record-breaking hot temperaturesWhile temperatures may be about to drop across much of the country, the next bout of fine weather is not far behind, he said.And it could be a royal knockout in terms off the weather with sunshine and warmth on the cards weekend, he added..He said: &ldquoThe introduction of cooler Atlantic winds may be temporary.&ldquoIt looks as though the jet stream, having dipped our way, may well retreat back northwards again. &ldquoMany longer range forecast models suggest that high pressure will extend across the UK, to ensure plenty of fine and settled weather through the middle of May.&ldquoWith the Royal Wedding&nbspapproaching, the nation will be hoping the rainclouds stay away.&ldquoI certainly don&rsquot expect a washout at Windsor on the 19th.

title: malaysian election 2018 results key dates Malaysia election process explained
story: Malaysians queue to vote in today's general electionAll 222 seats of the Dewan Rakyat were up for grabs along with 505 seats in 12 out of 13 regional legislative assemblies.The last Parliament was formally dissolved on April 7 by Prime Minister Razak but would have been automatically dissolved on 24 June when its five-year term was due to come to an end.The Malaysian constitution requires a general election to be held in the fifth calendar year unless it is dissolved earlier due to a motion of no-confidence or at the request of the Prime Minister.                Malaysia election 2018 results: Najib Razak clings to powerThe Dewan Rakyat is made up of 222 MPs who are all elected for a five-year term.The seats are distributed between the 13 Malaysian states in proportion to the states' voting population and MPs are elected from single-member constituencies that each elects one representative to the Dewan Rakyat using the first-past-the-post voting system.If one party obtains a majority of seats, then that party is entitled to form the Government, with its leader as Prime Minister.If the election results in no single party having a majority, there is a hung parliament when the options for forming the Government are either a minority government or a coalition.Millions of Malaysians have cast their votes in an election pitting the country's leader against his 92-year-old former mentor                    REUTERS1 of 14People line up to vote in Kuala LumpurMalaysia does not practice compulsory voting or automatic electoral registration and the voting age is 21.Around 15 million people were eligible to vote at the country's 8,253 polling stations in today&rsquos electionThe vote was conducted by the Election Commission of Malaysia which falls under the jurisdiction of the Prime Minister's Department.The leader of the party commanding a majority of support in the Dewan Rakyat is the person who is called on by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong to form a government as Prime Minister, while the leader of the largest party not in government becomes the Leader of the Opposition.Malaysian opposition leader former PM Mahathir MohamadThe previous General Election witnessed 133 governmental seats and 89 non-governmental seats filled the Dewan Rakyat.Razak&rsquos government side had 44 safe seats and 34 fairly safe seats, while the opposition, led by 92-year-old former PM Mahathir Mohamad, had 33 safe seats and 18 fairly safe seats.Results are already coming in with Mr Mohamad claiming he has won enough seats to form a government.

title: malaysia election results 2018 exit polls najib razak mahathir mohamad
story: Early exit polls show the Prime Minister's coalition Barisan Nasional (BN)&ndash which has been in power for 61 years &ndash clings to a slight lead with 24 of Parliament's seats.Unofficial results show 92-year-old Pakatan Harapan (Alliance of Hope) leader Mahathir Mohamad &ndash a former Prime Minister and mentor of Najib - has clinched 17, reports Reuters.A total of just 122 is needed to secure victory, while 505 state seats are also being contested in the 14th general election of Malaysia.Malaysia election 2018 results: Najib Razak looks set to cling to power                Malaysia election 2018 results pictures: Who will win the election?...                When is the Malaysia election 2018? Key dates, process explainedIt is though Najib will win overall, despite losing key states such as Kelantan, Penang and Selangor.An election-eve opinion poll suggested that support for BN was slipping and Mahathir's alliance would land the most votes in peninsular Malaysia, home to 80 percent of the population in this Southeast Asian nation.Najib 64, said he was confident of victory when he cast his vote, following what he has described as vicious attacks on him during the campaign.Millions of Malaysians have cast their votes in an election pitting the country's leader against his 92-year-old former mentor                    REUTERS1 of 14People line up to vote in Kuala LumpurA ticketing system was placed to ensure orderly voting. As many as 15 million registered Malaysians went to cast their vote.Results are expected to be announced overnight after a hotly-fought contest.How does the Malaysia Election work?Malaysia election results: Mahathir Mohamad has claimed his party has wonElections in Malaysia exist at two levels: federal level and state level.Federal level elections are those for membership in the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of Parliament, while state-level elections are for membership in the various State Legislative Assemblies.The winner of the election works on a basis of whoever gets the most seats throughout the election - even if it does not win the popular vote.At the federal level, voters elect the 222-member House of Representatives to Parliament.

title: Malaysia election 2018 results najib razak wins
story: Najib Razak casts his vote in Malaysia's general election 2018Mr Najib, who has been power since 2009, held a commanding lead over his 92-year-old rival and former mentor but has seen the tide has turned against him, even in the rural strongholds of the ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition.Officials from his Umno party have warned if he wins fewer than 130 seats out of a total of 222 he is likely to face a leadership challenge.Mr Najib has faced growing criticism over his his role in a huge financial scandal, where $2.6bn from a government fund he was overseeing was embezzled and spent around the world and $681m of it was alleged to have ended up in his personal bank account.                Malaysia election 2018 results: 15 million voters head to the polls                When is the Malaysia election 2018? Key dates, process explainedBut experts believe the election will be decided by a large silent majority, many of whom live in remote rural areas of Malaysia and traditionally have voted for BN.Among rural farmers and ethnic Malay in states such as Sabah and Sarawak, Mr Najib demands huge loyalty for the generous subsidies given out and issues such as the 1MDB corruption scandal do not factor in their voting choices.For him to lose to Mr Mahathir, it would require a huge swing away from him in these heartland areas.The country's rising cost of living is a hot topic, and a Goods and Services Tax (GST) introduced in 2015, as well as the depreciation of the ringgit, have hit many Malaysians.Millions of Malaysians have cast their votes in an election pitting the country's leader against his 92-year-old former mentor                    REUTERS1 of 14People line up to vote in Kuala LumpurMr Najib has promised to almost double cash handouts to low-income households.Research analyst Rashaad Ali from the S Rajaratnam School of International Studies said: The big issue is cost of living &mdash other issues like corruption are secondary to Malaysians' bread and butter.No one has been convicted of any crime connected to 1MDB and Malaysia's attorney general has cleared Mr Najib of any wrongdoing.Zeger Van Der Wal, associate professor at Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy, said: We certainly can conclude that the prime minister is a very skillful political player.&ldquoAnd when there's a skillful politician that still has considerable popular support, you'll also see that they tend to survive scandals like this.Investors are watching closely as Malaysia is one of six emerging economies where elections have the potential to move markets, according to UBS.And with the GST and currency proving major voter concerns, the outcome of the election will likely affect the country's economic policies.Peter Mumford, director of Asia at risk consultancy Eurasia Group, said: A weakened Najib would have less political capital to push ahead with post-election fiscal consolidation, though he would not likely go as far as scrapping the unpopular GST, which has exacerbated concerns over the rising cost of living.Mr Najib's plans for infrastructure projects and a pivot toward China could also be in jeopardy if victory goes to Mr Mahathir.

It was a real shock because the times when I would talk to her on social media - we had gone our separate ways, I‚Äôd followed the business world, she was in a whole other world - but everything had looked normal.‚ÄùAsked what had gone wrong in that part of the family, Elizabeth said: ‚ÄúI have no idea. title: global britain customs union sun says
story: As MPs return to Parliament this week, Tory rebels think they can twist the Prime Minister‚Äôs arm and force her into membership of the customs union, or at least an imitation of it.They‚Äôre all over the airwaves slamming their free-trading colleagues as ‚Äúhard Brexit‚Äù ideologues.But those pushing for us to strike out on our own are far from rabid extremists. They‚Äôre following the only possible logic of the Referendum result, the Prime Minister‚Äôs own speeches and the Tory manifesto ‚Äì a document that those remoaning rebels seemed perfectly happy with when they were re-elected off the back of it last year.If a deal between the UK and Brussels stops Britain making independent trade agreements with the rest of the world, or leaves us subject to rules over which we have no say, then it would be a betrayal of the 17.4million people who wanted out of the EU.The Europhile backbenchers know that. If they win this battle, they‚Äôll have succeeded in keeping us in Europe by the back door. They‚Äôll mark it up as a victory, but this isn‚Äôt a political game.It would be an insult to democracy and hold our economy back.We must start work on building a truly Global Britain ‚Äî now.THAT brickies and nurses are now having to scrimp and save for six-figure deposits is nothing short of a national scandal.No recent Government has been willing to grasp this particular nettle.Our housing crisis has been brewing for decades and sorting it will require real radicalism from the new Communities supremo James Brokenshire.He must fight the Nimbys head-on and demand Treasury cash to unleash a building programme.He must also tear up planning laws and look again at the Green Belt. title: baldness cure shampoo
story: Scientists found the therapy promotes speedy sprouting of hair in lab tests.It works by blocking a naturally-occurring protein that kills off growth and plays a key role in male baldness.Experts are ‚Äúoptimistic‚Äù the treatment, known as WAY-316606, could one day help millions of men.Researchers found the drug ‚Äì originally developed for osteoporosis ‚Äî boosted growth from human hair follicles in just two days.They now hope to carry out clinical trials on blokes with thinning patches.Lead researcher Dr Nathan Hawkshaw, from Manchester University, said: ‚ÄúThe fact this new agent, which had never even been considered in a hair loss context, promotes human hair growth is exciting because of its translational potential: it could one day make a real difference to people who suffer from hair loss.‚ÄúI‚Äôm very optimistic it could work. In lab tests, the drug started promoting growth in hair follicles in just two days ‚Äì that‚Äôs pretty quick.‚ÄúWe are looking at using it as a topical treatment, a gel or shampoo that could reach the follicle.‚ÄùDr Hawkshaw said there are no known side-effects of the bone drug.The study, published in the journal Public Library of Science Biology, involved hair follicles donated by more than 40 men struggling with baldness.The tissue all started sprouting hair within days of being treated with the drug.Male-pattern baldness is the most common type of hair loss, affecting around half of all men by 50 years of age.Currently only two drugs, minoxidil and finasteride, are available to treat the condition.But both have side-effects and do not always work.The only other option to balding blokes is hair transplantation.Scientists have also discovered a new drug that could cure baldness, especially in patients with alopecia.Researchers at¬†Columbia University Medical Center found 75 per cent of patients with moderate to severe alopecia showed significant hair regrowth after taking the drug ruxolitinib.By the end of the treatment the average hair regrowth among patients was 92 per cent.Previous research has found that football players are more likely to go bald as repeated¬†trauma to the hairline can cause chronic inflammation, which in turn can cause¬†alopecia.Male pattern baldness is the most common type of hair loss in men.It is a genetic condition that follows a pattern of a receding hairline and hair thinning on the crown of the head.It is caused by a hormonal and genetic predisposition.Each strand of hair you have sits in a tiny hole in the skin called a follicle.Generally, baldness occurs when the hair follicle shrinks over time, resulting in shorter and finer hair until, eventually, the follicle does not grow new hair.There are several options available to men who suffer from hair loss.Hair transplants:¬†Removing tiny plugs of hair from areas where the hair is continuing to grow and placing them in areas that are balding. The procedure usually requires multiple sessions and may be expensive.Minoxidil:¬†A solution that is applied directly to the scalp to stimulate the hair follicles. It slows hair loss for many men, and some men grow new hair but hair loss will return when you stop using it.Propecia:¬†A drug that interferes with the production of a highly active form of testosterone that is linked to baldness. It slows hair loss. It works slightly better than minoxidil but hair loss will still return when you stop using this medicineOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: press freedom vote government control
story: The bill being debated is important, because it will give people more control over how their personal data is stored and used.However, new amendments put forward by certain MPs are an attempt to hijack the bill and to use it to force newspapers to sign up to a state-sponsored system of Press regulation, as well as to hold another long and costly inquiry into events of up to a decade ago.I chaired the Parliamentary Select Committee that helped to uncover the phone hacking scandal.The behaviour of those involved was shocking and it rightly led to criminal prosecutions of those responsible.It also resulted in the setting up of Lord Leveson‚Äôs inquiry, which sat for 15 months and cost more than ¬£5million.Since that time, a lot has changed.A new body, the Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO), has been set up to replace the old Press Complaints Commission.It is fully independent and has powers to investigate complaints and to impose penalties on publications that break the rules, including front page corrections and fines.Most recently, it is introducing a new system of compulsory arbitration which the UK‚Äôs 15 best-selling newspapers have agreed to join.This will give people low-cost access to justice without having to employ lawyers or go to court.This new system of Press regulation fulfils almost all of the requirements set down by Lord Leveson in his inquiry.In all important respects it meets the tests for recognition under the Government‚Äôs Royal Charter.However, for reasons of principle, not a single national publication, nor the vast majority of the local press, has been willing to join a government-approved regulator.It is hard to see why some now wish to persist with an inquiry into the past when so much has changed.Today, it is not the printed press that exerts influence and makes money but social media and the internet giants.Nor is it clear why they should want to impose massive penalties on newspapers that do not sign up to an alternative regulator that has been approved by the state.Under their proposals, newspapers that choose to remain outside the Government‚Äôs system of Press regulation will be liable to pay all the claimants‚Äô costs of legal actions brought against them on data protection grounds as well as their own, whether they win or lose.At a time when many newspapers are struggling, a lot would not survive.Some of those pressing the amendments have their own grudges against the Press.They have been unhappy about stories written about them in the past.I too bear the scars of having had tabloid press stories written about my private life.Some of these were inaccurate or purely salacious.That is the price of being in the public eye, although I also know the distress that such coverage can cause to others, particularly the families of those involved.However, the alternative of state controls on the Press is far more damaging and dangerous.The media play a vital role in a free society in exposing wrongdoing and holding governments to account.It is no accident that it is the world‚Äôs most authoritarian states which impose strict controls on their media.Britain is seen across the world as a bastion of liberty and human rights.It is essential that we reject these amendments and not put that reputation at risk.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we title: m62 motorway woman sunbathes traffic jam heatwave
story: Lily Willets, 27, spent 20 minutes sunbathing on the M62 after motorists were brought to a standstill over the Bank Holiday weekend.Lily was on her way to Blackpool with partner Sam Wadsworth when an oxygen tanker caught fire, causing three hours of delays during sizzling temperatures.Full-time mum Lily from York, North Yorkshire, said: ‚ÄúWe were driving down the M62 having just stopped at the services when we saw a big cloud of smoke, and all of sudden came to a standstill.‚ÄúWhen we got stuck in the traffic jam I spat my dummy out as we had all these plans ‚Äì I‚Äôm quite a diva.‚ÄúThis was at about 12.30pm and on social media it said it was looking like we‚Äôd be there until 5pm, we were gutted.‚ÄúI suddenly thought bugger this, I want a tan. While I‚Äôm here I might as well make the most of it.‚ÄùShe added: ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt bothered about people looking at me.‚ÄúThe way the weather was I thought there might be people further down the motorway doing the same but I guess not given the number of people who commented on the picture I posted on social media.‚ÄúI‚Äôve never done it before but at the time I just did what I needed to do.‚ÄúI sunned myself for about 20 minutes then there was talk that people were going to start moving so I jumped back in the van. I got a lovely tan.‚ÄùSam said: ‚ÄúIt was a case of making the best of a bad situation - might as well get a tan while we were there.‚ÄúWe were just sat on the barriers on the central reservation and then Lily got the blanket out.‚ÄúLily‚Äôs crazy but that‚Äôs what I love about her.‚ÄùThe traffic started moving at 3.45pm but as the couple were still an hour away from Blackpool decided to travel to nearby Clitheroe instead.Lily said: ‚ÄúIf I ever got stuck in another traffic jam like that I‚Äôll definitely do it again, but next time Id make sure I take more pictures.‚Äù

title: pay petrol pump prevent obesity
story: Paying for petrol in store leaves you open to the temptation of buying chocolates and sweets, one of the country‚Äôs leading obesity experts has said.Susan Jebb, an Oxford University professor and adviser to Public Health England on obesity, said banning junk food at checkouts would help change Britain‚Äôs relationship with food, reported¬†The Times.It comes as restrictions on promotion and advertising of junk food is being considered by Parliament.Professor Jebb told MPs on the health select committee yesterday: ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre trying to do is change the food environment.‚ÄúOne of the things that really strikes me is the sheer availability of food everywhere: DIY shops, clothes shops, goodness knows what, that now have sweets on the checkout.‚ÄúI think those impulse purchases do matter. When I do talks on obesity one of my top ten tips is pay at the pump, don‚Äôt go into the kiosk, and people really get that.‚ÄùIndustry claims that regulations on advertising are already tight are a ‚Äúshocking sham‚Äù, MPs were told, as junk food adverts regularly appear on YouTube and Facebook.Dan Parker, an advertising executive turned obesity campaigner, said rules that prohibited online advertising for junk food on sites where more than a quarter of the audience were children were useless.‚ÄúThis code does not include Google, or any search engine,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúIt does not include YouTube, it doesn‚Äôt include Facebook, Twitter or any other social networks.‚ÄúIt is a shocking sham. If I type My Little Pony into Google, do I see junk food ads? Yes.‚ÄùStephen Woodford, chief executive of the Advertising Association, said: ‚ÄúMy view, which is in line with a consensus of academics, is that advertising has a small impact on food preference.‚ÄúIt has even less impact on overall diet and even less on overweight and obesity.‚ÄùObesity levels in the UK have more than trebled in the last 30 years and, on current estimates, more than half the population could be obese by 2050, according to the NHS.About 27¬†per cent of the UK population is considered obese and a further 34 per cent are considered overweight, according to the¬†latest Government statistics.Carrying excess weight, even if its just a little, has been linked to¬†type 2 diabetes, stroke, heart disease and¬†11 different types of cancer.World Cancer Research Fund estimates¬†25,000 cases of cancer could be prevented every year in the UK alone if everyone was a healthy weight.According to the World Health Organisation heart disease was the biggest killer in 2015 followed by stroke, both of which were responsible for 15 million deaths worldwide.

title: labours emily thornberry suggests little miss books should be renamed because little implies women are worth less
story: The Shadow Foreign secretary suggested the Little should be dropped from the female versions of the kids books because it implied that women were less.She told ITVs Good Morning Britain today: I dont like this thing about being little. I think thats my problem with the Mr Men books.Why do you have Mr Men, and then, Little Miss? Its something about women being less.Her comments come after an academic study said the book series was sexist because female characters are shown as less powerful.It found the Little Miss characters have to be saved in the stories more than half the time, while the Mr Men only need saving less than a third of the time.Plus the male characters also get more to say in the books as theyre given on average 12 extra words.The findings are based on 47 Mr Men and 34 Little Miss books from 1971 to 2014.It concludes: Generally female characters were more passive, had less direct speech and relied on being saved more than male characters.Ms Thornberry said if the titles were tweaked were changed to Ms, then shed have no problem being known as Ms Trouble.In another segment of the show, journalist Eleanor Mills claimed the classic books reinforced gender stereotypes - and even compared long-armed character Mr Tickle to shamed film producer Harvey Weinstein.She explained: I think they are sexist. If you look at the narratives in them the women in them are always having to be saved by Mr Strong or somebody like that, and they often have to do domestic tasks for Mr Lazy.The topic sparked a furious debate online.Many Good Morning Britain viewers hit back, saying the study was nonsense.One wrote online: The world has gone made.Another said: I loved the Mr Men in the 70s and read them to my children. They are just fun.One more wrote: They are meant to be for children, stop taking the fun out of everything. #PoliticalCorrectnessGoneMad.

title: meghan markles madame tussauds waxwork revealed complete with engagement ring given to her by prince harry

title: labour mps plot to defy jeremy corbyn and vote to keep britain in the eu single market
story: Yesterday‚Äôs defeat for Theresa May in the Lords triggered a vote in the lower chamber on a Norway-style deal with Brussels post-Brexit next month.But that set Mr Corbyn on a collision course title: hero neighbour scales high rise building to save woman trapped on her window ledge as her flat went up in flames
story: Pyae Nway, 30, was dubbed Spiderman after expertly scaling a pipe to help a woman stranded on her window ledge in Yangon, Burma.Dozens of people were trapped inside the cramped homes when a fire broke out on Saturday morning.Mobile phone footage shows several people stranded several feet up with black smoke billowing out of their flats.Many residents, including a couple and woman named San Thien, are seen crouched over air conditioning units waiting for fire crews.Then Nway comes into shot, clambering up the metal pipe up to his terrified neighbours.He grabs Thien by the hand and cradles her with one arm before slowly shimmying back down to safety.At this point, other residents follow his lead by climbing out of windows and traversing down scaffolding poles.Nway later said: I heard people shouting, Im going to jump, Im going to jump, so I climbed up to help.He said he could not stand by and let the woman to perish in the fire.Nway added: I didnt think there was time to wait for the fire brigade. title: theresa mays customs mess gives jeremy corbyn rare pmqs victory but stand in speaker sir lindsay hoyle the real winner in john bercows absence
story: Given the Labour boss usually has a complete aversion to talking about all things Brexit, he appears to have caught the Prime Minister off guard with a withering opening belter, asking if she agreed with Boris that the complex tariff collecting plan was ‚Äúcrazy.‚ÄùThe PM never really got into her stride after that, while for once Mr Corbyn‚Äôs rigid script actually had some decent and tricky questions on it.And he had a point that ‚Äú23 months since the referendum‚Äù Brits should be able to expect better answers than the garbled waffle Mrs May offered up today.Given the Labour chief has his own headaches to deal with - not least facing a massive rebellion on staying in the Single Market when the EU Withdrawal Bill in two weeks‚Äô time - it seems extraordinary that Mrs May seemed incapable of counter attacking.It was a rare reminder of what Labour could be achieving every week with a leader able to put ruthlessly exploit the bitterly divided Cabinet more than once in a blue moon.And there was something else rather refreshing about today‚Äôs weekly Commons bout - not least the fact it did not run on for nearly an hour.The leaders had wrapped up their pithy and succinct exchange in under ten minutes - not just because the PM had nothing to say - but because she was able to mumble her poor answers without a constant interruption from the Speaker.With the embattled John Bercow on official business elsewhere, up stepped his deputy.And if it was an audition for the top job the Labour MP Sir Lindsay Hoyle knocked it out of the park.He spoke for the nation when he told toadies asking long winded planted questions to ‚Äúget on with it‚Äù, and he was able to do it in four words rather than four minutes of smug speeches every week.Gone was the gone was the patronising sneering and¬†hectoring¬†lectures at MPs designed to get the Speaker on the telly.Usually MPs shout ‚ÄúMORE‚Äù when their respective leaders have a good day, but today they rightly united in shouting to see ‚ÄúMORE‚Äù of Mr Hoyle.FINAL SCORE: Theresa May 1 ‚Äì 5 Jeremy CorbynOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen royal wedding prince harry meghan markle windsor horse show pictures
story: Her Majesty, 92, basked in the sun and was wearing a pale blue cardigan as she dressed down for the Royal Windsor Horse Show on Wednesday.On May 19, the same grounds at Windsor Castle will be hosting the wedding of Prince Harry and American actress Meghan Markle.And it seems the royal equestrian fan was keen to make the most of her spare time before the big day as she sat in her private box to watch the annual showjumping competition.She was seen holding a pink rosette after one of her horses finished fifth in the five-day equestrian event which is located in the private grounds of the castle.The Queen has not missed the event since it was first held in 1943 in a bid to help raise money for the war effort.Her Majesty was wearing a blue cardigan and was spotted laughing and chatting during the first day of the event in WindsorHarry and Meghan‚Äôs wedding will have been timetabled to allow the Queen to attend the show and to make sure the nuptials did not clash with its organisation.The prince and his bride will wed in the castles gothic St Georges Chapel a week on Saturday, when thousands of spectators and media will descend on the town.The Queen was at the horse show without the 96-year-old Duke of Edinburgh, who is recovering from a hip replacement operation, with his attendance at the wedding yet to be confirmed.Last year, Philip was seen carriage driving with his ponies on the morning the Windsor Horse Show began.It comes as Prince Charles said he cant wait for his son‚Äôs wedding and he added that the occasion is going to be very special day for everybody.He and wife Camilla will be among the 800 guests at the chapel to witness the wedding of the year.

title: tourists peer over cliffs west bay dorset broadchurch pictures
story: Shocking pictures show tourists blatantly ignoring warning signs to look over the sandy cliffs at West Bay, Dorset - despite the steep rock face ready to crumble at any moment.In one photograph, one man in a blue t-shirt can be seen leaning over the edge of the sandstone cliffs that have featured in the TV crime drama Broadchurch.Another image shows a group of bathers lying down at the foot of the sandstone cliffs - despite fears they are prone to rock falls without warning.Ian Guy, duty controller for HM Coastguard, said: Its a well-known fact that the cliffs along the UK coastline are continually eroding, with pieces falling from them that can be just a few small rocks or as large as a car.It‚Äôs impossible to predict when the next piece might fall or how big it will be.Weve seen a number of cliff collapses around the UK coastline in recent months and its very clear that cliffs are very unstable in places and we really cant stress enough how important it is to keep back from the edge.There is no safe place to be. Some of the cracks that have appeared have been several feet back from the edge.He said that the selfie culture had increased the danger near rock faces, with people keen to capture a dramatic photograph of themselves.He said: No selfie or photograph is worth risking your life for.It comes after pictures emerged showing parents allowing their toddlers to peer over the edge of the dangerous Beachy Head cliffs for a photo.Coastguards and the local council have put up prominent signs urging members of the public not to stand too close to the cliffs in case of a landslip.Mr Guy added: When standing at the bottom of a cliff, we would always advise people that they shouldnt stand less than the height of the cliff away. That means that if the cliff is 25 metres high, dont go closer than 25 metres towards it.Our advice would always be to take notice of any warning signs and fences in place, be responsible and don‚Äôt take an unnecessary risks.In 2012 tourist Charlotte Blackman, 22, was crushed to death when a huge landslip occurred as she walked under the cliffs further along the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site at Burton Bradstock.Tragically, in June last year, South Korean student¬†Hyewon Kim died after taking a trip to the Seven Sisters cliffs alone.She had asked a stranger to take her picture but as she jumped in the air for a shot,¬†the 23-year-old lost her footing and plummeted from the cliff edge.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary school pupils given bread water lunch forget dinner money
story: Jamie-Lee Heath described the policy at Mount Pleasant Primary School in Shrewsbury, as ‚Äúshocking‚Äù and said it showed ‚Äúno compassion whatsoever‚Äù.It had been set out in a newsletter, but the 30-year-old says she only became aware of it after receiving a text from the school warning her that her nine-year-old daughter Madison owed ¬£4.40 for two lunches.The policy states that if arrears exceed ¬£6.60 ‚Äúwe will only be able to offer bread, fruit and water to pupils‚Äù.It also says that pupils will have to sit away from others to eat.Kitchen designer Jamie-Lee explained that Madison was charged ¬£2.20 after accidentally leaving her packed lunch in her father‚Äôs car.The following day she also went to school without a packed lunch, prompting a further charge and the text.She said:I called up immediately and explained I would pay online straight away as I didn‚Äôt realise she had arrears or no dinner money but also asked about what she would have been given if I hadn‚Äôt managed to read the text in time.This is when the bread, fruit and water policy was explained to me. It had been mentioned in a previous school newsletter but I must admit I hadn‚Äôt read it properly.I then wrote a status on my personal Facebook page alerting other parents who may have missed the newsletter about what was happening.Myself and others also agreed that the fact the child would be taken away from their friends and given a different ‚Äòlunch‚Äô in a separate room seemed like a punishment to a child and could easily create upset or bullying opportunities.I also find it appalling that if indeed a parent was struggling to pay lunches for whatever reason, it is the child who would suffer.‚ÄùThe school said they reluctantly introduced the policy after a number of parents persistently failed to pay for their kids‚Äô meals - forcing them to write off the money.They insisted pupils with no packed lunch or dinner money are provided with bread and butter, a selection of fruit and vegetables from the salad bar and a choice of milk or water.They apologised for the lack of clarity around the issue and added: ‚ÄúWe take utmost care to listen to and help parents and carers who may be experiencing financial difficulties so that we can ensure their child still receives a meal.‚ÄúFor the children who continue to arrive at school with no meal plan in place, we will endeavour to work with the responsible adults, including those who persistently don‚Äôt pay, to find the best solution possible.‚Äù

title: chester races 2018 boodles may festival pictures today
story: As the sunshine clings on before rain and thunder barrels in to end the spell of hot weather, revellers headed to the Chester race course today.The ladies wore brightly coloured dresses as they got into the festival spirit, and the men also dressed up - donning sharp suits.The fashion stakes were high as women arrived in glamorous outfits ready to place their bets on the horses.In the hopes of an extra bit of tanning time before the clouds roll over the country this evening, shoulders and legs were out in force.Off-shoulder dresses in summery colours appeared to be the flavour of the month as eye-catching outfits filled the crowds.The day at the races comes as the¬†heatwave which blessed Brits for the Bank Holiday will come to a close today as temperatures tumble.At least an inch of rain is set to fall across the entire country, dampening the blistering 28C¬†heatwave¬†as the UK rapidly cools down in a noticeable drop.A spokesman for the Met Office said: The eastern areas are seeing the best of the sunshine and the bright weather. We are looking at highs of 22C in the south east.Its a different story in the West though, clouds just starting to come in and a band of rain appearing Northern Ireland, western Scotland.That bank of rain will reach south eastern England overnight.Mondays temperatures marked the hottest early May Bank Holiday since it was introduced 40 years ago, beating the 23.6C in 1999.Those hoping for a repeat scorcher next weekend will be disappointed, as it is forecast to be cooler and more unsettled.Britain has some way to go to beat the hottest day in May on record - which was in 1944 when the temperature soared to 32.8C.The highest temperature ever recorded for the late spring Bank Holiday was also in 1944, with highs of 32.2C.Looking ahead to the royal wedding, the forecast is proving elusive, with the Met Office saying there was lots of uncertainty and low confidence surrounding the conditions on May 19.

title: north korea is directly assisting iran in developing a nuclear missile capable of striking israel claims report
story: An explosive report, obtained by Sun Online, details the Islamic Republic aggressive pursuit of a nuke-carrying rocket which can travel more than 1,200 miles.The report, compiled by the National Council of Resistance of Iran, details how the head of the Middle Eastern country‚Äôs nuclear programme allegedly travelled to North Korea for the rogue state‚Äôs third nuclear test in 2013.Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, dubbed the father of the Iranian bomb, arrived in the crackpot country using the pseudonym Dr. Hassan Mohseni, the report claims.Fakhrizadeh is said to have stayed at Hotel Koryo in Pyongyang while travelling with two other Iranian nuke experts.The Council of Resistance claims that their findings are based on a two-year investigation into¬†Fakhrizadehs alleged trip.In April 2015, shortly before Iran signed the US-led nuclear agreement, a delegation of North Korean nuclear experts spent a week in the Islamic Republic, according to the report.This was the third such visit by Kim Jong-un‚Äôs nuclear experts to Iran in 2015, claims the Council of Resistance.The report states: ‚ÄúThe delegates included nuclear experts, nuclear warhead experts, and experts in various areas of ballistic missiles, including guidance systems.‚ÄúThe North Korean delegations have also provided assistance and consultation in the areas of aerodynamics, missile body design, and electronic components of warheads.‚ÄùSpeaking with The Sun Online, Alireza Jafarzadeh of the Council of Resistance said Iran‚Äôs missile programme has been developed with ‚Äúdirect assistance‚Äù from North Korea.He said: ‚ÄúThe main nuclear-capable missile that Iran has developed known as Shahab is actually modelled after the North Korean Hwasong missile.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just that they just tried to copy them ‚Äì it‚Äôs beyond that. title: ants home invasion what to do
story: Heres all the information you need to know.Ants love your home, especially your kitchen as it is one huge source of food for the pesky insects.An scout ant will leave the nest in search of food, leaving a trail of pheromones.Once it finds food it will follow the trail back, leaving even more pheromones, which then other ants will follow as they go out for food.Soon enough youll have a whole army running all over the place in search of everything from grains of sugar to dirty dishes.Store all food away, ideally in airtight containers, if possible.Dont leave food outClean up any food and drink spills as soon as possible.Clean thoroughly, including cupboards.Wash pet bowls regularly - ants are also partial to cat and dog food too.Take out your rubbish regularly.Clean your entire kitchen with a natural, homemade anti-ant spray, made with one part water, one part vinegar - this destroys their pheromones.Hopefully this will mean the ants move elsewhere in their search for food.Use various ant deterrents such as¬†salt, chalk, curry powder, pepper and cinnamon and line doors and windows with any of these - but these might not be ideal if you have pets and/or small children.If you can follow the ants back to their nest find out how they are getting in and block up any holes with sealant, especially around doors and windows.Perhaps as a last resort, if you know where the nest is, open it up with a knife and then pour a kettle full of boiling water down it.A bit drastic but this will kill all the ants, including the queen.¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
